qas.question: What title did Darwin's book ultimately have?
What had Darwin wanted to name his book?

answers.text: An abstract of an Essay on the Origin of Species and Varieties Through natural selection

qas.question: Who convinced Darwin that his book needed a shorter, more compelling title?
What does the word "races" mean as referenced in Darwin's book?

answers.text: an alternative for "varieties" and does not carry the modern connotation of human races

qas.question: What is the extended name of The Origin of Species that is written on the title page?

answers.text: by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life

context: Darwin had initially decided to call his book <a1_0>An abstract of an Essay on the Origin of Species and Varieties Through natural selection<a1_0/>, but with <a2_0>Murray<a2_0/>'s persuasion it was eventually changed to the snappier title: <a0_0>On the Origin of Species<a0_0/>, with the title page adding <a4_0>by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life<a4_0/>. Here the term "races" is used as <a3_0>an alternative for "varieties" and does not carry the modern connotation of human races<a3_0/>—the first use in the book refers to "the several races, for instance, of the cabbage" and proceeds to a discussion of "the hereditary varieties or races of our domestic animals and plants".
